image.altText: A concept image for Hobart's Macquarie Point stadium.

props.synopsis: A three-storey, underground car park at Hobart's proposed Macquarie Point AFL stadium is the latest known exclusion from the building cost estimates, a parliamentary hearing is told.

title.children: More items revealed as not being budgeted for in Hobart's proposed stadium costings

image.altText: Hobart bus mall in Elizabeth Street

props.synopsis: Tasmania is to finally get a 'smart' ticketing system for the state's bus and ferry network at a cost of $35.4 million.

title.children: Tasmania promises 'smart' public transport payment usually reserved for major cities

image.altText: Two workers in Hi-Vis on a crane working on a powerline.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's Fair Work Commission has heard of four incidents deemed to have threatened community safety earlier this month during recent storms.

title.children: As storms crossed Tasmania, another storm was raging: inside the TasNetworks control room

image.altText: Cover of an old exercise book.

props.synopsis: The scuffed notebook in a box is found to be the important diary of an Antarctic expeditioner written at the height of the Cold War.

title.children: It looked like an old school book, but this tip-shop donation turned out to be much more interesting

image.altText: Two police officers take notes while talking to an unidentified woman.

props.synopsis: Coercive control can be "hidden in plain sight", according to training being rolled out to police officers, which seeks to help officers see a broader picture of family violence.

title.children: 'I was in shock': This domestic violence victim was labelled the perpetrator, but there's hope for new police training

image.altText: A woman in a World Central Kitchen shirt smiles at the camera standing in a cafe

props.synopsis: Foreign Minister Penny Wong will call for a new international declaration for the protection of humanitarian personnel following the killing of Australian aid worker Zomi Frankcom in Gaza earlier this year.

title.children: Australia to push world leaders to better protect aid workers after Zomi Frankcom's death in Gaza

image.altText: Smoke plumes coming out of a city scape.

props.synopsis: An IDF spokesman has presented aerial video of what he describes as Hezbollah operatives trying to launch a cruise missile from a civilian house in Lebanon, and a subsequent Israeli strike moments before it was launched.

title.children: At least 100 killed and 400 wounded as Israel launches air strikes on southern Lebanon

image.altText: A middle-aged Kurdish woman smiles at the camera in a posed but informal portrait shot.

props.synopsis: Cigdem Aslan, whose Australian passport is in the name of Lenna Aslan, was reportedly arrested at Istanbul Airport on suspicion of conducting activities for the PKK, a banned terrorist group in both TÃ¼rkiye and Australia.

title.children: Australian woman arrested in TÃ¼rkiye on suspicion of supporting banned Kurdish terror group

image.altText: Peter Dutton speaking publicly outdoors, wearing a suit with a yellow ribbon pinned on the lapel.

props.synopsis: Opposition leader Peter Dutton has said he would abolish the position of Ambassador for First Nations People on "day one" if elected, describing it as a "waste of taxpayer money".Â

title.children: Dutton vows to scrap new First Nations ambassador position if elected

image.altText: The Premier, Health Minister, and candidate and a youth worker stand in a line and smile outside a hospital.

props.synopsis: The Liberals promised $120 million over five years for a new cardiac centre for the state's north at the Launceston General Hospital, but the state budget revealed no funding allocation for the project.

title.children: Did you miss? ðŸ“£ Tasmanian Liberals blasted after 'priority' Northern Heart Centre election promise not funded in state budget

image.altText: A banner reading 'Coles' and, in the background, the Woolworths logo.

props.synopsis: The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission launches legal action against Woolworths and Coles, alleging the supermarket giants breached consumer law by misleading consumers through discount pricing claims on hundreds of products.Â

title.children: 'The conduct we are considering is very serious': ACCC launches action against Coles and Woolworths

image.altText: Diesel and Mia Dyson

props.synopsis: Harry and Charlotte celebrated their first wedding anniversary with a music festival for friends and family. Now, they are the organisers of a boutique festival in Tasmania's north-west.

title.children: Are 'smaller, boutique' music festivals the way to save live music from collapse?

image.altText: A young woman with brow hair stands at a podium

props.synopsis: Former Australian Greens leader Christine Milne is one of the former MPs helping a new cohort of women enter politics. She says while there's been "enormous change" for women since she first entered parliament in 1989, there's still work to be done.

title.children: 'We can make the system work for us': Breaking down barriers for women in Tasmanian politics

image.altText: A man speaks at a lectern

props.synopsis: Climate Change Authority head Matt Kean says expert advice differs to what Peter Dutton says about nuclear and renewables being companions not competitors.

title.children: 'Very different advice': Climate Change Authority chair Matt Kean contradicts Dutton on nuclear power

image.altText: Lachlan Murdoch stands at a lectern to give a speech. An image of a US flag is on a screen behind him.

props.synopsis: Rupert Murdoch's court battle with his children is about more than money. He's fighting to keep his media empire conservative

title.children: 'The day Rupert dies is the day Lachlan gets fired': The words that rocked the Murdoch empire

image.altText: Signs at coles and woolworths

props.synopsis: Hundreds of products were affected, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission alleges, including family packs of Oreos and throat lozenges.

title.children: Coles and Woolworths campaigns promised cheaper prices for years. Now they're accused of 'misleading' customers on more than 500 products

image.altText: A man, photographed from behind so his face isn't visible, looks downcast

props.synopsis: When Ezekiel landed in Australia as a guest worker two years ago, he was full of hope. Two years later, he is in limbo, destitute and homeless with the company that sponsored him being investigated for abuse and mistreatment of workers.

title.children: Crisis point in regional towns as modern slavery overwhelms local services

image.altText: Kim Jong Un speaks in front of microphones with a red and yellow flag in the background

props.synopsis: Kim Jong Un runs the "model dictatorship" in North Korea. Here's how he got here.

title.children: 'Publicly executed to send a message': The brutal regime of Kim Jong Un

image.altText: A cold glass of beer.

props.synopsis: David Littleproud faces a backlash from senior Liberals over the National Party leader's "freelancing" pledge to consider freezing beer excise under a future Coalition government.

title.children: Liberals pour cold beer on Littleproud excise freeze

image.altText: Donald Trump holds up a fist. A crowd is behind him.

props.synopsis: Former president Donald Trump says that he will not make a fourth consecutive run for the US presidency if he loses the upcoming election.

title.children: 'That will be it': Trump says he will not run again if he loses in November

image.altText: Rose Staleo

props.synopsis: The banking royal commission described the way in which mortgage brokers are paid as "conflicted remuneration" and "money for nothing". Customers don't care.

title.children: Three in four home loans are written by mortgage brokers, infuriating banks and delighting customers

image.altText: New Socceroos coach Tony Popovic sits a desk and answers questions from the media.

props.synopsis: Tony Popovic has been named the new head coach of the Socceroos, taking over after the sudden resignation of Graham Arnold.

title.children: Popovic named as new Socceroos coach ahead of crucial World Cup qualifiers

image.altText: Patrick Cripps smiles and gives a thumbs up at the Brownlow Medal count

props.synopsis: The AFL's biggest names gather for the game's night of nights to see Patrick Cripps take his second Brownlow Medal with a record 45 votes. Follow live.

title.children: Cripps takes second Brownlow Medal with record vote tally

image.altText: Daniel Ricciardo wipes his face

props.synopsis: Daniel Ricciardo may well have turned his final corner in a F1 car after an emotional interview following the Singapore Grand Prix.

title.children: Tearful Daniel Ricciardo 'aware it could be it' for his F1 career

image.altText: Side view close-up of pregnant woman touching her belly

props.synopsis: People who want to terminate their pregnancy after 28 weeks could be required to instead deliver their baby alive under proposed changes to laws in South Australia that decriminalised abortion three years ago.

title.children: MP pushes for births over abortions in proposed SA law changes

image.altText: An old gent in broad-brimmed hat and blue overalls leans on a messy office desk.

props.synopsis: Dick Daley has been yapping, tinkering and pumping fuel on the Atherton Tablelands for the past 60 years, at a service station he bought with the help of a 50-pound loan.

title.children: Servo owner hangs up the fuel pump at 94, offering 'driveway service' until last day on the job

image.altText: Anthony Albanese, Narenda Modi, Joe Biden and Fumio Kishida stand in a line next to each other.

props.synopsis: Here's four things Anthony Albanese's trip revealed about the Quad, leadership, language and life lessons.

title.children: Four takeaways from the prime minister's 48 hours in the US for the Quad

image.altText: Ben Zygier

props.synopsis: A new documentary aims to shed more light on the case of Prisoner X, who was identified as Australian man Ben Zygier. He'd been working as a spy for Mossad but his alleged crimes remain shrouded in secrecy.

title.children: How the man known as 'Prisoner X' went from suburban Melbourne to the heart of Mossad

image.altText: A man on a stage grasps his hands, while listening to someone

props.synopsis: Pony Ma's resurgence might seem like a positive signal of a more permissive market environment. But as we watch China's private sector grow, we should remember it follows China's unique playbook.

title.children: Are things looking up for China's tech billionaires?

image.altText: NT DV thumb

props.synopsis:
A litany of failures by Northern Territory police led to the collapse of an alleged domestic violence case against one of its own detectives.

title.children: 'Gross incompetence': How NT police botched alleged DV case against detective

image.altText: A crowd sits on sandy banks

props.synopsis: More than 2,500 people attended the six-day event's finale, set in the natural amphitheatre of Ormiston Gorge, Kwartatuma.Â

title.children: Curtain call for Desert Song Festival with director citing need for more arts funding

image.altText: Devni Vihara posing on a green lawn

props.synopsis: Women of Asian backgrounds reveal they've been told to "not be so ambitious" by earning more money than their partners.Â

title.children: Devni was told 'not to threaten' her ex-boyfriend's place by earning more money than him

image.altText: hand pulling condom out of pocket.

props.synopsis: New sexual consent laws come into effect from today, along with the criminalisation of stealthing.

title.children: Stealthing will be criminalised in Queensland from today. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: A still from a video showing rough winds collapsing the roller doors of shed.

props.synopsis: Garage doors blast open and tree branches become projectiles in footage which captures a tornado slicing through Victoria's High Country in August.

title.children: Footage shows fleeing kangaroos, garage doors 'imploding' as BOM confirms tornado passed through Victoria
